Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This comprehensive program supports strong academic skill building for scholarship recipients with activities and structures that enhance the living experience on campus in the first year, and career-building activities in the following three years. The overall objectives of the program are to increase achievement, retention, and interest in careers in the biosciences.

Freshmen and sophomores are required to live on campus in the Bio Living-Learning Community. In their fall semester freshmen year, students take a college success course taught by a Biology faculty member. In their second semester freshmen year, students take Careers in Biology, which is co-taught by a career counselor and a biology faculty member. Both courses are open to other students. Scholars benefit from block scheduling into science and mathematics courses for two years. In addition, tutors from the Pirate Tutoring Center at the college are being hired to attend courses with students and provide note-taking training and tutoring sessions as requested. A common academic advisor advises students until they declare their major in their sophomore year, after which they will be advised by the principal investigators.

Sophomores help recruit students for the next class. As upperclassmen, students are being guided and encouraged to undertake undergraduate research projects and/or internships. The academic performance of students is being assessed by their grades. Interviews and questionnaires given at the end of each academic year allow formative assessment of the program. A final questionnaire and follow-up assessment for two years after graduation is being used to collect data regarding future career plans.

This program with its combination of social, academic, and financial support is changing the culture of the university experience for these students and ensuring their success in bio-related careers and/or post-graduate education.

Intellectual Merit: The overall goal of the BioExcellence Scholarship program is to support academic achievement, so that recipients complete BS Biology or BS Biochemistry degrees in four years, leading to a career in the biosciences. Students with 3.0 or higher GPAs who are interested in majoring in Biology or Biochemistry are being supported in their coursework by intervention programs including peer tutoring, career information, and block scheduling for the first two years, followed by undergraduate research mentoring and internships in the biosciences to help guide students in career decisions.

Broader Impact: The program benefits 24 financially deserving students, primarily from eastern North Carolina. This region has a high poverty rate, low higher education achievement, and a large minority population. This student group can often struggle financially and academically. The program lends support structures to help them attain their goal of a university degree and career in the biosciences. Students enter a study to assess success of the interventions, and results are being disseminated to regional and national science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives for the BioExcellence Scholarship program at East Carolina University are to impact students, especially first-generation college students, by supporting excellence in biology or biochemistry coursework, and to promote retention above the current 80% freshman-sophomore rate so that within four years scholarship recipients will successfully complete BS Biology or BS Biochemistry degrees.  In addition, the BioExcellence Scholarship program will prepare students for the workforce and/or graduate/professional programs. 

The major activities of this grant project were to recruit, enroll, retain and to support the students in their college years to successfully complete a degree. The PI founded the Biology Living-Learning Community (BioLLC) of which the BioExcellence students were members. The PI and co-PIs have served as academic advisors for the BioExcellence students. We awarded scholarships to the all students who remained academically eligible for up to four years each, through a no-cost extension for a final semester in Fall 2017. We collected data on GPA, retention and graduation rates. We also collected data via interviews of the students before they graduated and have presented this data and the results for retention and graduation rates at two national conferences.

Significant Results/Intellectual Merit:

Retention: The first cohort was retained at a 6/7 or 85.7% rate. The second and the third cohort were each retained at a 78% rate (7/9). The fourth cohort, the largest one at 13, had a one-year retention rate of 100% (13/13). Thus, the average one year freshman to sophomore retention rate for all four cohorts was 33/38 or 86.8%, surpassing the original 80% goal.

Graduation: Our first cohort graduated with a 5/7 rate, or 71.4%, with an average GPA of 3.61. These were all STEM degrees (biology, chemistry and atmospheric science). The second cohort graduated with a STEM degree within four years with a 33% rate (3/9) with a 3.5 average GPA. Within the first cohort, three went into master’s degree programs, one went to pharmacy school and the other is teaching in a STEM field. For the second cohort, vocations after graduation varied as well: one of them is working in a non-STEM field, one is pursuing a STEM master’s degree, and the other is working in a STEM job.

Of those that did not yet graduate from the first cohort, one is pending graduation, and one had dropped out of ECU after one year. From the second cohort, of the six who were dropped from the program, two students were not retained at ECU after the first year and one left after two years due to low grades. Two others students were dropped from the program due to low grades, and another one due to changing to a non-STEM, pre-health major. The last student is now in dental school. The remaining two students are still pursuing their degrees. If one includes those who were dropped from the program but still graduated, four students in the second cohort graduated in four years, for a 4/9 four-year graduation rate, or 44.4%. This surpasses the university 4-year graduation rate of 39% for all students in this period.

Key outcomes:

  • Overall retention (first to second year) average over four years was 87%.
  • Overall four year graduation rate within the program (two cohorts to date) was 50% counting only those graduating with a STEM major, 56% overall.

Broader Impacts:

Some of our students have moved to pre-health disciplines. One changed majors to mathematics and one to atmospheric science, as well as some to social science disciplines such as psychology and criminal justice. We posit that as students mature while maintaining a high GPA and overall succeeding at ECU, they have joined other disciplines perhaps due to our initial support.

The demographics indicate that our scholarship is benefitting students from underserved groups. Our first cohort of six BioExcellence scholars is 100% first-generation and 33% minority. Our second cohort of nine BioExcellence scholarship recipients is 100% first generation and 22% minority (African-American). The third cohort of nine BioExcellence scholars is 78% first-generation and 22% African-American. We elected to award scholarships to a fourth and final group of students in the Biology Living Learning community starting in Spring 2016. We gave scholarships to all of them that had financial need; their high school GPA was 3.0 or higher. That group of 13 students was 100% first generation, 38% African American and 15% Hispanic.

Conclusions and lessons learned:

Through interviews, students shared that they greatly appreciated the cohort-building aspect of the BioLLC. We significantly increased one-year retention rates, which are especially low among students with this demographic. They noted that they would have liked to have more activities after the first year. That may be reflected in our 4-year graduation rates, which are better than the general student population, but still not where we would like them to be.
